awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Tidal disruption of near-Earth asteroids
awd_abstract_narration:
This collaborative project between Southwest Research Institute and the University of Maryland College Park studies how gravitational forces can reshape or tear apart near-Earth asteroids (NEAs).  “Rubble-pile” asteroids (which are loose collections of material) and comets are known to reshape or come apart, through a process known as tidal distortion and disruption, as they pass close to planets. This research team will use computer simulations with inputs from observations to examine how tidal disruption changes the population of NEAs. They will address topics such as how many fragments are created, what their orbits are, and how many odd shapes can be attributed to the process. This will provide important insight into their history and potential futures and has relevance to planetary defense. The broader impacts leverage the interest of the general public in NEAs to continue a long-running public outreach program and to build an accessible toolset and lesson plan for wide use.

Near-Earth asteroids are some of the closest and therefore best-studied objects in the Solar System, yet it is not known how pervasive the effects of tidal disruption could be among NEAs. This research team will model the interaction of rubble-pile asteroids having close flybys of terrestrial planets.  They will determine whether their soft-sphere discrete code can produce some of the irregularly shaped NEAs, re-process their surfaces, and alter the size and orbital distribution of near-Earth asteroids. Through accurate modeling of the surface interactions between particles, this group will capture the effect of frictional forces and irregular shaped constituent pieces for a complete suite of tidal disruption models. Testing over the entire range of possible encounter scenarios (close approach and velocity) for the terrestrial planets, including a range of spin states (spin axis orientation and spin rates) and internal structure (large interior blocks), will be used to create a catalog of outcomes necessary to estimate how widely this process has altered the near-Earth population and be able to estimate the bodies most likely to have been affected.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
When small bodies such as asteroids and comets fly by planets like the Earth, the gravitational interaction may distort or even disrupt the smaller body. There is evidence that the small-body population near the Earth has been influenced over time by such close encounters. The University of Maryland team contributed to the overall research project by simulating using computer code the effect of such gravitational encounters under the assumption (supported by observations, including spacecraft missions) that most small bodies are "rubble piles" consisting of loose aggregations of competent pieces. We improved the realism of the code by including the effect of irregular constituent shape on the encounter outcome. This work was a major component of graduate student Julian Marohnic's PhD thesis (awarded December 2023) and the research of PhD candidate Joseph DeMartini (thesis defense anticipated in the first half of 2025), under the supervision of Maryland PI Derek Richardson. Our contribution resulted in a published paper led by Marohnic and a submitted paper led by the overall study PI Kevin Walsh that is under review as of this Project Outcome Report.

In the first paper, we presented an approach for the inclusion of nonspherical constituents in high-resolution simulations of self-gravitating, colliding particles. We used aggregates composed of bonded spherical particles to model nonspherical components in rubble piles. Nonspherical grains confer additional strength and resistance to flow compared with simple spheres when subjected to stress like a gravitational encounter. Spherical particles on the other hand are easier to use when calculating gravitational and collisional effects, so the bonded-aggregate approach is a kind of "best of both worlds," providing improved realism at comparatively low computational cost. This paper focused on the numerical method, using gravitational encounters as one of the test cases. We found that the inclusion of nonspherical constituents has a measurable impact on simulation outcomes.

In the second paper, we argue that rubble piles subjected to planetary encounters may be resurfaced, distorted, reshaped, split into binary or higher-multiple systems, or fragmented entirely and that the outcome is affected by the shapes of the body's constituents. We investigate the effects of particle shape on numerical models of gravity-induced deformation and disruption using our numerical code described previously. We compare the results of close encounters between the Earth and rubble-pile bodies with differently shaped constituents and different numbers of constituent particles. We find that in energetic encounters that result in mass loss, rubble piles made up of nonspherical constituents may retain up to 50% more mass than those composed of simple spheres. Nonspherical constituents can also reduce the number of fragments produced by a violent disruption by up to 50% compared to simulations with spherical particles. We find little effect on the mass of satellites (gravitationally bound fragments) that end up in orbit around the largest disruption remnants. Particle shape also appears to have little to no impact on the overall shape of post-disruption remnants. The magnitude of these effects varies considerably depending on the specific constituent shapes in question. Overall, we find that constituent shape can significantly alter the number and mass of fragments in close-planetary-encounter simulations and should be accounted for as a contributing factor in studies of rubble pile evolutionary processes.
